column1: langsandculture 161961936893 "2017-06-18 11:03:42 GMT" http://langsandculture.tumblr.com/post/161961936893/so-you-want-to-learn-modern-greek-greek-language "progressiveresistance: If youâ€™re trying to learn Greek and find materials for learning online youâ€™ve probably run into some frustration because it seems like most of the information is geared toward learners of Koine Greek to read the Bible. Thatâ€™s all well and good
column2: but for those of us who are looking to learn modern Greek itâ€™s not terribly helpful.  With that in mind Iâ€™ve compiled a list of the materials that I found in my quest to self-study Greek that began in earnest about 1.5 years ago. Now keep in mind I had an excellent teacher (my girlfriend) who also served as my motivation
column3: but even if you donâ€™t have a close relationship with a Greek speaker you will at some point need to interact with proficient speakers to help move you to the next level of fluency. However
column4: the materials I outlined here should be enough to give you a very good start.  Learning Greek podcasts from the Hellenic American Union: The go-to audio-visual resource. Â 80 lessons (all FREE) with accompanying PDF transcripts. Â Be warned itâ€™s ALL Greek
column5: not a lick of English (or anything else) in it
column6: so youâ€™ll need a dictionary/textbook to go with it.  Teach Yourself Greek: The Greek edition of the venerable textbook series. Â Definitely worth a look.  Memrise: There are a surprising number of really good Modern Greek-English flashcard sets on Memrise (which uses a spaced repetition algorithm that I found very effective).   Wordreference: King of the online dictionaries
column7: at least in terms of variety   Neurolingo Lexiscope: See a word in Greek but canâ€™t work out its uninflected form? Â This is the tool for you (only 10 free searches a day
column9: last I checked)   Modern Greek Verbs: Everything you ever wanted to know about Modern Greek verbs. Â Seriously
column10: everything.   Greek Grammar: Excellent overviews of the main grammatical points of the Greek parts of speech   Harry Foundalisâ€™ Greek Language: Harryâ€™s a bit of a renaissance man
column11: which is awesome. Â His way of explaining verbal aspect in Modern Greek I found less awesome until I warmed to it
column12: but thatâ€™s just me: I like the technical
column13: linguistics jargon filled explanations coupled with charts of patterns and examples. Once I got past the presentation I could see what he was doing and it has a certain brilliance. Â The rest of his grammar (and phonetics) stuff is top notch.   Cooljugator: Conjugates most common Greek verbs.  These resources
column14: watching lots of Greek TV (thank you
column15: YouTube) and listening to lots of Greek music (thank you YouTube again)
column16: and practicing constantly (thank you to my girlfriend) took me from zero to fairly fluent in about 1.5 years. Â Now
column17: I already spoke a lot of languages and I had help
column19: but this should be a good start on your Greek learning journey. ÎšÎ±Î»Î® ÎµÏ€Î¹Ï„Ï…Ï‡Î¯Î±! " False text

column1: langsandculture 158821559873 "2017-03-25 19:13:59 GMT" http://langsandculture.tumblr.com/post/158821559873/how-the-eu-starves-africa-into-submission-capx "commissarchrisman: It is estimated that Africa imports nearly 83 per cent of its food. African leaders are seeking ways to feed their peoples and become players in the global economy.In the second edition of The New Harvest: Agricultural Innovation in Africa
column2: I argue that Africa can feed itself in a generation. However
column3: efforts to achieve such an ambitious goal continue to be frustrated by policies adopted by Africaâ€™s historical trading partners
column4: especially the European Union.There are at least three ways in which EU policies affect Africaâ€™s ability to address its agricultural and food challenges: tariff escalation; technological innovation and food export preferences.African leaders would like to escape the colonial trap of being viewed simply as raw material exporters. But their efforts to add value to the materials continue to be frustrated by existing EU policies.Take the example of coffee. In 2014 Africa â€”the home of coffeeâ€” earned nearly $2.4 billion from the crop. Germany
column6: earned about $3.8 billion from coffee re-exports.The concern is not that Germany benefits from processing coffee. It is that Africa is punished by EU tariff barriers for doing so. Non-decaffeinated green coffee is exempt from the charges. However
column7: a 7.5 per cent charge is imposed on roasted coffee. As a result
column8: the bulk of Africaâ€™s export to the EU is unroasted green coffee.The charge on cocoa is even more debilitating. It is reported that the â€œEU charges (a tariff) of 30 per cent for processed cocoa products like chocolate bars or cocoa powder
column9: and 60 per cent for some other refined products containing cocoa.â€The impact of such charges goes well beyond lost export opportunities. They suppress technological innovation and industrial development among African countries. The practice denies the continent the ability to acquire
column10: adopt and diffuse technologies used in food processing. It explains to some extent the low level of investment in Africaâ€™s food processing enterprises." False link

langsandculture 152422504648 "2016-10-28 13:07:43 GMT" http://langsandculture.tumblr.com/post/152422504648/these-gorgeous-animated-shorts-celebrate-11-of "reclaimingthelatinatag: To residents of the Americas
column2: Europe can seem like a tower of Babel with dozens upon dozens of languages crammed into a small geographical space and vying endlessly for dominance or survival. On this side of the world things are much simpler: English
column6: and a few Dutch speakers make communication generally much smoother across the continent
column7: along with a few New World Patois thrown into the mix for good measure. At least so the thinking goes. In reality
column8: the American continent is a place of vast linguistic diversity
column9: with more language families found solely in Mexico than in the entirety of the European continent. And with each language comes a particular vision of the world
column11: a treasure trove of wisdom accrued over the centuries and codified in words and idioms. Yet these languages struggle desperately for survival in the midst of a post-colonial landscape dominated by a small handful of European languages. Consciously or unconsciously
column12: indigenous tongues are often viewed as backward and those who speak them stigmatized
column13: relegated to the margins of official society for refusing to adapt to rules set by colonizers through violence and subjugation. " False link
